circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: This is a partial skull cap found by a passerby on the shoreline at Remley's Point Boat Landing in Charleston, SC.  This particular geographical point projects into the harbor and human remains are commonly recovered here as they follow the tides toward the ocean.  The skull cap is weathered and shows no sign of autopsy.

circumstances.description: Diversion canal near Cross Generating Plant
circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: On July 17, 2007, contractors conducting dredging operations for Santee Cooper near the intake of the Cross Generating Plant found a severed, badly decomposed human foot floating in the diversion canal connecting Lake Marion and Lake Moultrie (or Santee Cooper Lakes) in the Cross/Pineville areas of Berkeley County, South Carolina. Sex, race, and age unknown. NFI available.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: On the afternoon of October 21, 1971, two university students discovered a body floating in the Congaree River while they were walking across a railroad bridge.  The body was that of a female and was caught on tree limbs near the train trestle.  She was estimated by the Calhoun County Coroner to be between 17 and 35 years old and "probably white". The body was intact but bloated and wearing a blue skirt, one silk stocking, and a lavender colored slip.  The Coroner estimated that the body had been in the water for approximately 15 to 20 days.  Unfortunately, the original autopsy report cannot be located.  The remains appear to have been autopsied, with the head and hands removed, presumably for printing and odontological analysis.  After initial efforts to identify the body failed, the decedent was buried on Calhoun County property in a marked grave.  These remains were exhumed in 2019 as part of further efforts to identify this decedent using NAMUS and DNA testing. Further testing for genetic genealogy efforts have revealed the decedent to have mixed African and European ancestry suggesting she may have been culturally labeled African American.

conditionOfRemains.name: Not recognizable - Decomposing/putrefaction
conditionOfRemains.localizedName: Not recognizable - Decomposing/putrefaction

clothingAndAccessoriesArticles.description: blue skirt, 1 silk stocking, lavender slip according to coroner's notes from 1971

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: On August 16th at approximately 1100 hours, members of a construction crew discovered an exposed bone in a neighborhood flanked by marshland. The bone was then transported to the Folly Beach Public Safety headquarters for safekeeping. We subsequently retrieved the bone from Folly Beach Public Safety headquarters and transported it back to the Charleston County Coroner's Office for storage and further analysis. The bones were analyzed and determined to be not of medicolegal significance. According to data collected on ArchSite, the location of the site is relative to a federal fort from the Civil War. After consideration, no steps for exploratory excavation were taken.

clothingAndAccessoriesArticles.description: A dark blue, short-sleeved baseball jersey (Rawlings brand, size L) is found wadded up between the head and the right shoulder.  Several loose teeth are found on this garment.  The shirt is completely buttoned-up but is inside out.  A stylized "G" logo at left front breast is consistent with the logo of the Greeneville Flyboys (formerly the Greeneville Reds), a minor league baseball team out of Tennessee.  A large number "3" is on the back.  There are no obvious holes in this garment.

A short-sleeved shirt (George brand, size 2XL) is found on top of the torso.  The raglan sleeves are red while the rest of the shirt is dark gray.  The forearms are partially inside the sleeves and the decedent may have been wearing this shit.  The shirt may have ridden up during movement/transport, and since the head is separated from the torso, the shirt may have slipped forward, displacing onto the torso where the forearms remained inside.  Referral to original scene photos may clarify this.  There is a 3-centimeter wide, triangular-shaped hole near the lower left front hem.

The decedent is wearing heavily decomposed denim pants (Lee brand, original color is gray?).  No size label is found, and the waistband is too degraded to measure waist size.  The top button is undone and the zipper is half-way down.  Three mini bottles of Jim Beam whisky are found in the rear left pocket.  One cigarette butt is found in the right front pocket.  The fabric of the pants tightly adheres to the skin on the legs and easily tears.

The decedent is wearing Nike Monarch athletic shoes, white with blue trim (US size 11).  The left shoestring is loosely tied, while the right shoestring is not tied.  Tread wear on the soles indicates the wearer chronically inverted their feet while walking (weight was placed on the outer edges of the feet rather than evenly across the sole of the feet).  This wear pattern is slightly more evident on the right shoe.  Both feet are encased in greenish-yellow ankle socks with patterned grips on the soles.  Such socks are commonly distributed in jails and hospitals.

physicalFeatureDescriptions.description: If antemortem imaging of the skull is found, a positive identification can be made by matching vault suture patterns, meningeal vessels, frontal sinus pattern, and the antemortem fracture to the right side of the decedent's head.  Antemortem chest x-rays could be used to match the cervical ribs and other unique skeletal traits found on this individual to include an ossified thyroid cartilage, a medially curved right clavicle (due to the cervical rib complex?), and a long sternum with an ossified xyphoid process.  Antemortem dental records would also provide a quick identification.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: On an unknown exact date in 1977 a skeleton was uncovered by a bull dozer in Edgefield County. The skeleton was found buried in a field appoximately 1 1/2 - 2 feet deep. This location was said to have been within a mile of a migrant labor camp. The remains were found wearing only a pair of pants, no shirt or undergarments were located. Estimated buried two years before finding in 1977. Any necessary reports from 1977 are trying to be located at this time.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: This human skull was discovered in a wooded area between Crane Church Road and Blue Ridge Terrace, Columbia, SC by a local resident. Officers searched the surrounding area and recovered no additional skeletal remains. The condition of the skull suggested it had not been buried but more likely discarded in the area. It may also be of nineteenth century or earlier origin as suggested by dental features of the skull.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: This is a cranium purged from an ME's cold case collection and given to an anthropologist in 1992.  Upon retirement, the anthropologist returned the cranium to the county of origin, which was Charleston County.  There are no law enforcement or autopsy reports.  The anthropologist noted that, based on the condition of the cranium, the time since death was probably 5+ years.  Although they appear to be identical, this case is not a duplicate of NamUs UP# 9589 (1992A00001).

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery:
(December 29, 1987) Decomposed human remains were found on the property of Michelin Corporation at Donaldson Center by two men attempting to apprehend an escaped calf. Remains were found in two separate locations within close proximity of each other.  Skeletal remains were transported to Greenville Memorial Hospital for autopsy/examination as well as forensic odontologist examination.
The estimated decomposition time is 3-6 months

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: A well nourished, moderately decomposed white male was discovered dead on June 12, 1984 lying along highway in Oconee County, SC.  He was discovered dead by a SC Highway Department worker while cutting grass.  He was found approximately .5 miles from the South Carolina / Georgia state line.  No identification was found on the decedent or with personal belongings.   A passer-byer reported to authorities he had given a man a ride approximately two weeks prior that fit this description; it was possible the decedent was a migrant worker in Florida and was headed north for the summer; he reportedly had never married and perhaps had relatives described as "rich" in the Philadelphia, PA area.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery:
On 10 October 2007, a human skull was found in the front yard of a residence on  James Island, SC.  

On 12 October 2007, the remains were transferred to Dr. Suzanne Abel for an anthropological analysis.  Her report revealed that the skull belongs to a black female in her 20s to 40s at the time of death.  Further, there are no obvious antemortem or perimortem alterations observed.  Time since death is estimated to be at the minimum over 2 years, and likely longer.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: A partial human skull (calvarium only) was discovered in a crawl space beneath a house by an exterminator on December 6, 2002.  Investigation and excavation beneath the residence by a forensic anthropologist and archaeologists revealed no further skeletal remains.  Ground penetrating radar survey of the surrounding area revealed no evidence of buried remains or graves.  The skull appears to be quite old based on taphonomic features.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: Found in a pile of shell hash. Nothing but oyster shells and a fossilized shark vertebra nearby. It was near the tide line and the tide was coming back in pretty quickly so the concerned citizen picked it up before it drifted away.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: While looking for shells on Morris Island, parts of a human skull were found by a Samaritan. She left the scene with the fragments and reported them to law enforcement a few days later as she realized they looked more human than of animal bones.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: A human skull was pulled in on a fish line by a woman out fishing at Lake Marion. The skull was recovered from about 25 feet of water under the U.S. 301-15 bridge in Santee on Labor Day. South Carolina Department of Natural Resource's divers discovered additional portions of skeletal remains two days after the initial discovery. It was reported that the skeletal remains were wrapped in a steel cable around a 200-pound piece of metal.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery:
Young to middle aged Hispanic male.  He is approximately 71 inches tall with a medium build.  He died sometime between July 12-19, 2001.  Due to the state of preservation it was not possible to obtain fingerprints.  

The deceased was wearing black jeans, a black belt, work boots and a t-shirt.  The shoe lace from the right boot was missing.  The shoe string was found tied around the decedents right wrist.  A backpack was found in the vehicle that contained personal items such as toothpaste and toothbrush, a Spanish bible, business cards and a social security card.  The social security card was determined to be fake.

conditionOfRemains.name: Not recognizable - Decomposing/putrefaction
conditionOfRemains.localizedName: Not recognizable - Decomposing/putrefaction

clothingAndAccessoriesArticles.description: boxer shorts, dark colored jeans, brown belt, pair of socks, brown work boots
T-shirt that was found pulled over the decedent's face inside out at the scene

physicalDescription.headHairDescription: dark in color and up to 4 inches long.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: This is an isolated cranium with no provenience, found in the Charleston County Coroner's Office evidence room with no documentation.  Anthropological analysis indicates that it originates from a black male, aged 30-50 at the time of death.  There is no evidence of trauma or pathology.  Time since death is estimated to be 5+ years.

physicalDescription.eyeDescription: No soft tissue associated with cranium.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery:
Human skull found near bridge
Published on 08/22/06 in the Post & Courier
Staff report 
MOUNT PLEASANT  A family on a fishing excursion Sunday afternoon found a human skull near the base of the Wando Bridge, authorities said. 

The Charleston County Coroner's Office confirmed the skull was human, but did not know how long it had been there. Testing was expected to take at least a week, Deputy Coroner Dottie Lindsay said. An initial inspection did not reveal any obvious signs of trauma. 

A Mount Pleasant couple and their two sons, ages 10 and 11, were in their small boat when the husband spotted a black object on the shoreline around 2 p.m., according to a police report. At first he thought it was an anchor. 

After calling 911, the husband scooped up the skull with a life preserver and moved it farther up the bank so the rising tide would not carry it away, the report states. The family met Mount Pleasant police officers at Remley's Point boat landing and took them back to the spot.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: On 24 February 2010, one human femur was recovered from the beach near the dikes on Morris Island, South Carolina.  Anthropological analyses indicates the bone is from a male (possibly white), aged 20-50 at death.  There is no evidence of trauma or pathology on the bone.  Time since death is estimated to be several years.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: These skeletonized remains are unidentified.   They were purged from a pathologist's office and given to an anthropologist for teaching purposes.  The anthropologist retired, gave the remains back to the county coroner from where they originated.  Previous personnel are now gone so there is no information; no coroner, medical examiner or law enforcement records can be found.  The anthropologist's notes indicate injuries that occured before death might help identify him.  No injuries that might suggest foul play are seen.

conditionOfRemains.name: Not recognizable - Near complete or complete skeleton
conditionOfRemains.localizedName: Not recognizable - Near complete or complete skeleton

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: Hispanic male, approximately 32 years old, was found dead in Gilbert, SC on 02/17/2016.  The decedent was located at a rental property that he had been residing at with at least one other individual.  Both gentlemen were undocumented immigrants, and we have been unable to positively identify the decedent.  We have received some possible names for the decedent, but none of those could be verified.  We are seeking assistance with identifying the decedent, so that his family can be notified and arrange for disposition.

conditionOfRemains.localizedName: Recognizable face

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: Property owners were clearing underbrush from a wooded lot at 750 South Beltline Boulevard when they discovered skeletal remains and clothing. The remains were scattered over an area of several hundred square feet by scavenging animals. The area is a flood plain near a creek.

conditionOfRemains.localizedName: Not recognizable - Partial remains with soft tissues

physicalFeatureDescriptions.description: The skeletal remains have healed facial and nasal fractures suggesting that the individual may have had facial scarring. Additionally, the remains have healed right rib fractures indicating blunt trauma to the chest.

The individual was missing all of his teeth antemortem and probably did not wear dentures based on significant bone loss in his jaws. His jaw may have appeared crooked during life due to asymmetry of the lower jaw.
